resources.string:
Own safety first! 

►Assess the accident. 

►Is it safe for yourself? If not "KEEP DISTANCE" 

►Press the arrow to continue

►Warn bystanders.. 

►Get there attention. 

 ►Make them aware of the dangerous situation 

 ►Try to avoid more casualties..

►Mark or eliminate acute hazards. 

►Remove or mark danger elements. 

►Fore example: Close a road next to an accident.. 

►Ask bystanders for help!

Call or ask somebody to call the emergency service. 

Tell...

►What happened.. 
►Where (address).. 
►how many victims you have seen.. 

 Press the image for...

If victim is in a danger zone: Move victim to a safe area. 

 Ask for help to move victims out the danger zone. 

 Think about your own safety. Do not take risks. 

 If it is too dangerous. Keep safe distance, and wait until the fire department arrives!
Can not find address. Check or internet is working?
Is victim involved in an accident? Or do you see serious injuries

Was the victim involved in an accident? Be aware there is a risk of whiplash. 

»Is the head in an unnatural position? 

»Or victim complains about pain in or around his neck? 

»Damage in the area! e.g: victim is in a heavily damaged car. 

►Do not move the victim or as little as possible. 

►Stabilize the neck with our hands. 

►See picture, ask an bystander to do this..
Back button does not work. Read dialog
Verify that the airway is free, so the patient can breathe.

By choking there is something in the airway, what has to be removed. 

Tell the patient what you are going to do. 

 ►Stay behind the patient. 
 ►Push his head slightly forward. 
 ►See figure above. 
 ►Hit 5 times with your hand palm vigorously between his shoulder blades. 

 ►If this fails, knock again 5 times little more powerful. 
Repeat this if necessary 2 times. 

If above fails, try the following. 

 ►Stay behind the victim, 
 ►Place your right fist under his diaphragm. 
 ►Put your left hand on your right fist. 
 ►Brace yourself. 
 ►Powerful pull your fist back. 
 ►See figure below. 
 ►Tell the patient what you are going to do.

By a small child or baby. 

 ►Keep the head downwards. 
 ►Do not hit hard!! 
 ►See figure..

By an unconscious patient, check the airway. Make sure the victim can breath. 

 Open the mouth and remove possible: blood, mucus, vomit.. 

 Below are 2 ways to open the mouth
check or the tongue is not swallowed

Turn an unconscious patient on his back. 

Look, Listen, Feel: 
 ►Look or his chest rises. 
 ►Listen for exhale. 
 ►Feel (with your face) for exhale.
►Press button below: "To count 15 seconds long the breathing". \n\n►A countdown progressbar will help you measure the time.
Enter the number of breath you counted.

►Newborn and Infant: 30-60 breaths per minute 
►Toddler (1-2 years): 24-40 breaths per minute 
►Preschooler (3-5 years): 22-34 breaths per minute 
►School-age child (6-12 years): 18-30 breaths per minute 
►Adolescent (13-17 years): 12-16 breaths per minute 
►Adult: 12-18 breaths per minute
Enter the number of breaths you counted between the bleeps.
The respiratory rate is %d per minute.\n\n
By a Baby: a normal respiratory rate is between 30 and 60.
By a Toddler: a normal respiratory rate is between 24 and 40.
By a Preschooler: a normal respiratory rate is between 22 and 34.
By a Child: a normal respiratory rate is between 18 and 30.
By an Adolescent: a normal respiratory rate is between 12 and 16.
By an Adult: a normal respiratory rate is between 12 and 18.

%d indicates a weak respiratory rate. Advice is to determine the pulse rate. 

Or count again.

%d indicates cardiac arrest. Advice is to start CPR.

Or count again.

%d indicates an healty rate. Advice is to press Next. 

Or count again.

%d indicates a very high respiratory rate. It is very unlikely than an unconscious person breath this fast. Advice is to count again. 

 If the victim became unconscious because of breathing to fast(Hyperventilation). Than it is likely that the victim will recover soon. In this case the advice is press Next.
By a Baby: a respiratory rate higher than 60 could indicate hyperventilation
By a Toddler: a respiratory rate higher than 42 could indicate hyperventilation
By a Preschooler: a respiratory rate higher than 36 could indicate hyperventilation
By a Child: a respiratory rate higher than 30 could indicate hyperventilation
By an Adolescent: a respiratory rate higher than 24 could indicate hyperventilation
By an Adult: a respiratory rate higher than 24 could indicate hyperventilation
\n\n Press the advice button or count again for 30 seconds.
\nButton for 3 times a loop: of 30 cpr followed by 8 seconds time for 2 rescue breaths.
\nButton to start or stop cpr rhythm.

►Read the instructions below careful before doing anything

 ►If possible, bare torso.
 ►Get on your knees beside the victim.
►Cross fingers together (see picture).\n ►Place hands on the middle of the chest, above the diaphragm.

»Press the button: "Start CPR + Rescue Breathing loop".
 ►Keep elbows straight, press victims chest down from your upper body.
 ►Press the chest down 6 cm or 2,5 inches.
 ►Press on the rhythm of the sound.

►After 30 times CPR, the sound stops for 8 seconds. In those seconds give victim 2 rescue breaths

 ►Open the mouth, by lifting the chin.
 ►Squeeze with your other hand his nose.
 ►Mouth to mouth and exhale vigorously.
 ►2 rescue breaths, after 8 seconds the rhythm start again. 

If you find the loop too confusing. Press button: Start CPR flow. Than you hear an non-stop cpr rhythm loop, with a rate of 100 CPR / minute
Inspect the breathing or continue cpr.
Number is invalid. Choose a lower number.
The best place to find the pulse rate is on the throat. See pictures below
Or take the pulse. See pictures below
►Press the button below to measure 15 seconds long the heart rate. ►Count the rate between the bleeps.
►Enter how many heart beats you counted between the bleeps

From a age of 10 years and above: A save heart rhythm is between 60 and 100 per minute.

 you measured a pulse rate of %d a minute.

 There is a weak respiration, and victim is unconscious. 

 If the heart rhythm is low and irregular or chaotic, ►START CPR. 

 If the heart rate has a normal value. Press: ►Continue. 

 or measure again.
With the weak respiration and a heart rate of %d per minute, the advice is: ►CPR
By a baby or a small child: \n►tilt the elbow sideways. \n►Feel with two fingers on the inside of the upper arm, see pictures.
►feel with your fingers, not with your thumb.

You measured a pulse rate of %d per minute. 

 By a baby a save heart rhythm is between: beats per minute

 » First month of life 70-190
 » Between 1 and 11 months 80-160
 » One- and two-year-olds 80-130
 » Three- and four-year-olds 80-120
 » Five- and six-year-olds 75-115
 » Between seven and nine years 70-110
 » From 10 years of age 60-100


There is a weak respiration, and victim is unconscious. 

 If the heart rate in combination with the age of the baby is to low, start CPR. 

 If the heart rhythm is irregular or very chaotic, start CPR.

 If the heart rate has a normal value. Press: continue. 

 or measure again.
With the weak respiration and a heart rate of %d per minute, the advice is CPR
\nButton for 4 times a loop: of 15 CPR followed by 8 seconds time for 2 rescue breaths.

►Start with giving 5 rescue breaths. Cover the mouth and nose with your mouth, blowing five rescue breaths. These should each last about one second, and the chest should rise with each one. Take a second to let the air come back out of the baby.\n\n
►►From here, read the instructions below careful before doing anything
►If you are alone place your hands as on the photo above.\n\n ►When you have a helper, one person does the CPR, he places his thumbs as on the photo below.

►Press the button: "Start CPR + Rescue Breathing loop". \n►Compress chest at least 1/3 the depth of the chest (about 4 cm or 1 ½ inches), 15 times just below the nipple line \n►Press on the rhythm of the sound.

►After 15 times CPR, the sound stops for 8 seconds. In those seconds give victim 2 rescue breaths 

►Open the mouth, by lifting the chin. 
►Cover the mouth and nose with your mouth, blowing 2 rescue breaths. These should each last about one second, and the chest should rise with each one. Take a second to let the air come back out of the baby. 

►2 rescue breaths, after 8 seconds the rhythm start again. 

►If you find the loop too confusing or if you have a helper. Press button: Start CPR flow. Than you hear an non-stop cpr rhythm loop, with a rate of 100 CPR / minute. Count out loud to 15.
Inspect the breathing or continue cpr.

Now the airway is clean, we observe the breathing frequency.. 

 ►If the breathing is very fast, then it is likely that the patient is hyperventilating. 
Hyperventilation happened a lot in panic situations.

►Posture stuffiness on one side of the body(chest), can indicate a collapsed lung. 

The lung on the painful side is not working. 

Place the patient in a sitting position. 

(e.g: Legs stretched on the floor, back against a wall.)
Is the patient heavenly injured on his chest, then it may be that one lung leaks from the outside. \n\n►Clean the wond and tape it on 3 sides off. Only do this if you know how to do this.
If patients becomes unconscious, put him in the recovery position with the injured side on the ground. \nSo the healthy lung is not impede

Scan the body for bleedings, Onderzoek het lichaam op bloedingen, following four causes can be deadly. 

►►Arterial bleeding. 
►►Internal bleeding. 
►►Burns. 
►►Snakebite.


Arterial bleeding. 
►If you see a heavy pulsating bleeding. Press button: ►Heavy bleeding. 
Small bleeding are not life threatening.

Internal bleeding: 

To check the patient on internal bleeding press hard on a fingernail, the nail will color white. 
►Look or the nail colors back to normal within 3 seconds. If patient has very cold hands press hard on the forehead. 
►Does the nail or forehead not coloring back within 3 seconds than it is likely that patient is in shock. 
►Blood does not return, because of heavy internal bleeding. Patient is in danger. 
 Be aware.. Even patients who are awake and talking, can bleed inside to death.

►Lay patient in shock posture, with legs up. 
►So that blood can flow from the legs to the chest and brains. 
►Keep checking breathing until the ambulance takes over. 
Tell the medic: NO CAPILLARY REFILL
Is the victim bitten by a snake? Press snakebite
If you see burns or the clothing of the victim is burned. ►Press button Burns

Is the respiratory rate faster than 1 breath in every 2 seconds, then it is likely that the victim is hyperventilating. 

The body exhales more CO2 out, than it produces. 
A body need C02 to control the breathing. 

►Tell the victim to hold his breath for a few seconds. Help him by counting very slowly to 10. And let the victim breath out on every count. 

►If this fails. Let the victim keep a hand before his mouth. So the victim will inhale the same air as he has just exhaled. Now the CO2 level in his body will rise again. 

►If possible, make from your own hands a bowl shape, ad hold that on his mouth. 

►If the victim lost his consciousness, lay him flat on the ground. Optionally with his legs a little off the ground. 
►Keep checking his breathing. Likely the respiratory rate will return to normal, and the victim will recover. 

►If the victim stops with breathing or the situation deteriorated: press button below.

Try to determine the level of consciousness. 

There are 4 levels: 
►Alert: Victim is awake, and gives clear answers on questions. 
►Verbal: Victim is awake, but makes a confused impression. 
►Pain: Victim is unconscious but responds to a pain stimulus. (only give pain stimulus if you know how to do this). 
►Unresponsive: Victim is unconscious, but does not respond to a pain stimulus. 

If victim is Alert tell him:"That help is on the way.." 

If victim is Verbal: Keep talking to him, try to get his attention.
If victim is unconscious and there is no sign of neck injuries. Lay the victim in the recovery position.

Make sure the victim is not suffering form external elements like sun, wind, heat, cold, rain. Make his situation more comfortable. 

If you ask the victims questions this acronym AMPLE can be useful. You can collect information for the medic. 

►Allergy: 
 »Are you allergic to something? 

►Medication: 
 »Are you currently taking any sort of medication? 
 »Are you under any medication? 

►Past Illness/History: 
 »Are you sick? or 
 »Have you been sick recently? 

►Last Meal 
 »What have you eaten today? 
 »Any alcohol, or drugs? 

►Events/Environment: 
 »What happened before the accident? 
 »What was the victim doing before he become unwell? 

This information can be very helpful for the ambulance. 

Repeat ABCD until the ambulance arrive.
for more information, or quick links press Menu.
Press start button If you are ready to count...
To translate this application in your language, or for improvements or changes inside the application. Please contact us by email

Please note that this application is a tool, a protocol. Based on medical knowledge and experience. 

Each situation is different... 

The author can not be held responsible for incorrect use of this application. 

The author assumes no legal responsibility for use of this application. 

Always use your common sense. Use the information as a tool, not as the ultimate truth.

►Stay calm, get safely away from the snake. 
►The less the victim moves the bitten site, the less likely the venom will be spread through the body and cause damage. 
►Have the victim lie down with the affected limb lower than the heart. 
►Call the emergency service. 
►Remove any rings, bracelets, boots, or other restricting items from the bitten extremity. (It WILL swell.)
►Mark the bite. Encircle only, so the bite can be found back after a swelling

►Apply a light constricting band about 5 cm above and below the bite, however never place the bands on either side of a joint (such as above and below the knee or elbow). 
►This band should be made up of wide, soft material, which could be a handkerchief or a shredded t shirt. 
►The band should only be as tight as the band the nurse applies when taking a blood test. 
►The purpose of constricting bands is to restrict lymphatic flow, not blood, so they should not be too tight. 
►Check pulses below the bands and readjust the bands as necessary when they tighten due to swelling.

►Treat for shock and preserve body heat. 
 ►If the snake is dead take it with you to the hospital. 
 ►If the victim has to walk out, sit calmly for 20-30 minutes to let the venom localize at the site, then proceed calmly to the nearest source of help. 
►Try to avoid unnecessary exertion which will stimulate circulation of the venom.

►Cool the skin with water. 

►Cool in and around the wound, not the whole body. 

►Cool with lukewarm water, not with ice. 

►Do not remove any fixed burned clothing from the wound. 

►Keep cooling until the ambulance takes over. 

►Be aware of hypotermia. Cooling is only for the wound. 

►By a burn as big as a coin, cool at least for 20 minutes.
